article.title: Alyattes_of_Lydia
article.paragraph: more footnotesJanuary 2013Alyattes, king ofLydia(619560 BC), considered to be the founder of theLydian empire, was the son ofSadyattes, of the house of theMermnadae.
article.heading: Life
article.paragraph: For several years he continued the war againstMiletusbegun by his father, but was obliged to turn his attention towards theMedesandBabylonians. On May 28, 585 BC, during theBattle of Halys (585 BC)Battle of Halysfought againstCyaxares, king of Media,Eclipse of Thalesa solar eclipsetook place; hostilities were suspended, peace concluded, and theKzlrmak (river)Halysfixed as the boundary between the two kingdoms.sfnChisholm1911

Alyattes drove theCimmeriansfromAsia Minor,Herodotus, 1.16; Sergei R. Tokhtasev "Cimmerians" in the Encyclopedia Iranica (1991), several nineteenth-century summaries.with the help of war-dogs.Polyaenus, 7.2He further subdued theCarians, and took severalIoniancities, includingzmirSmyrnaandColophon (city)Colophon. Smyrna was sacked and destroyed with its inhabitants forced to move into the countryside.sfnChisholm1911
He standardised the weight of coins (1 Stater = 168 grains of wheat). The coins were produced using an anvil die technique and stamped with the Lion's head, the symbol of the Mermnadae.
He was succeeded by his sonCroesus.sfnChisholm1911His daughterAryenis of LydiawasQueen consortofAstyages, King of Media.

article.heading: Appearance in "The Histories"
article.paragraph: InHistories (Herodotus)The Histories,Herodotusrecounts how Alyattes continued his father's war against Miletus. According to Herodotus, Alyattes invaded Miletus annually to burn their crops over the course of several years. The troops left the horses and houses untouched so that the Milesians could plant a new crop, which the Lydians would then burn the following year. This continued until the end of the war eleven years later.cite bookHerodotusThe Histories1998Oxford World's ClassicsNew York978-0-19-953566-89
